questions.text: In non-immune hydrops which of the following is NOT seen:

options.label: A
options.text: Skin oedema

options.label: B
options.text: Ascites

options.label: C
options.text: Large placenta

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiomegaly

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiomegaly Hydrops is characterized by excess fluid in two or more body areas such as the thorax, abdomen or skin. It is often associated with hydramnios and a hydropic thickened placenta.

Highyeild:

Hydrops is of 2 varieties: Immune hydrops Nonimmune hydrops • It is due to Rh isoimmunisation • It is accumulation of extracellular fluid in tissues and serous cavities without evidence of circulating antibodies against RBC antigens • It accounts for 1/3rd cases of hydrops fetalis • It is due to conditions other than Rh isoimmunisation • It accounts for 2/3 cases of hydrops fetalis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Increased skin thickness (> 5 mm) / skin oedema (first sign seen on USG). Option: B. Ascites - The fetus is in the Buddha position with a halo around the head . Option: C. Placental enlargement - Pleural effusion

Extraedge:

Non immune hydrops: Hydrops occurring due to a cause other than Rh incompatibility is called Nonimmune Hydrops It can be caused by a number of conditions (there is an exhaustive list given on p 627 Williams 23/e, Just go through it). questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida with 11 weeks of gestation presents to the OPD for abortion as the pregnancy had occurred due to failure of contraceptive. She has no comorbidities. She was prepared for a manual vacuum aspiration. Her vitals were normal, lab investigations showed- Hb -12g/dL, WBC and platelets normal. The coagulation profile showed normal values. Her blood group was identified as B negative. On examination, her husband’s blood group was O positive. The patient should be administered-

options.label: A
options.text: 50 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 72hrs of the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: 300 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 72hrs of the procedure

options.label: C
options.text: 50 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 24hrs of the procedure

options.label: D
options.text: 300 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 24hrs of the procedure

questions.correct_answer: A. 50 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 72hrs of the procedure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50 µg Anti D gammaglobulin within 72hrs of the procedure The given clinical scenario points towards abortion in a female with an Rh-negative blood group. Anti-D gammaglobulin is administered in all cases to prevent complications in the succeeding pregnancies. Dose: Anti-D-gammaglobulin is administered intramuscularly to the mother at 300 µg following delivery. All Rh-negative unsensitized women should receive 50 µg of Rh-immune globulin IM within 72 hours of induced or spontaneous abortion, ectopic or molar pregnancy or CVS in the first trimester. Women with a pregnancy beyond 12 weeks should have a full dose of 300 µg. Generally, a 300 µg dose will protect a woman from fetal haemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood. Option B. is administered in all Rh-negative pregnancies beyond 12 weeks.

Highyeild:

Indications for Anti D immunoprophylaxis: First trimester Later pregnancy Miscarriage Ectopic (medically or surgically managed) Hydatidiform mole Threatened abortion Medical or surgical MTP Chorionic villus sampling Miscarriage Amniocentesis Fetal blood sampling Antepartum hemorrhage External cephalic version Routine antepartum prophylaxis Delivery Intrauterine fetal death Manual removal of placenta

Extraedge:

Antibodies titre: Antibody titre can be measured by automated tests. m A titre of < 4 IU/ml is considered as safe. Titre of > 4 IU/ml or 1: 8 denotes isoimmunization. Titre of > 10 IU/ml (in some countries > 15 IU/mL) denotes severe hemolysis-it.com also called the 'critical titre' Time for performing indirect Coombs test. In primigravida - at 12 weeks or at booking visit and if it is negative (i.e. mother is not immunised), it is repeated at 28th. Boo In multigravida - at 12 weeks or at booking visit and then at monthly intervals after 28 weeks.

questions.text: A 27-Year-old G2P1 with 37 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen and contractions associated with the show. Her previous delivery was a home delivery and she hasn’t had ANC for the present gestation. She has not had any lab investigations or prior use. Her blood samples were sent for lab investigations. Her blood group was identified as A negative. On examination of her husband’s blood group was O positive. She has no history of any injection in previous pregnancy as it was a home delivery. She was explained about the complications. She had a vaginal delivery of a stillborn fetus as shown below. True statements are all except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common complication of Rh isoimmunization pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Tissue anoxemia and metabolic alkalosis seen

options.label: C
options.text: Damage to the liver occurs causing hypoproteinemia

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal death is due to cardiac failure

questions.correct_answer: B. Tissue anoxemia and metabolic alkalosis seen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tissue anoxemia and metabolic alkalosis seen The given clinical scenario points towards Rh isoimmunization pregnancy with Hydrops fetalis . The image shows a stillborn edematous infant due to hydrops fetalis. HYDROPS FETALIS: Excessive destruction of the fetal red cells leads to severe anaemia, tissue anoxemia and metabolic acidosis . These have got adverse effects on the fetal heart and brain and the placenta. Hyperplasia of the placental tissue occurs to increase the transfer of oxygen but the available fetal red cells (oxygen-carrying cells) are progressively diminished due to hemolysis.

Highyeild:

ABO incompatibility: If ABO is present along with Rh incompatibility it protects against Rh isoimmunization. ABO blood group compatibility of mother and fetus - ABO incompatibility protects against Rh isoimmunisation. When ABO-incompatible fetal red cells enter the mother's bloodstream, they quickly combine with the naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B agglutinins and are neutralised by sequestration in the liver. On the other hand, ABO-compatible fetal red cells will persist in the mother's circulation and thus stimulate the immune response.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. This is the most serious form of Rh hemolytic disease (HDFN). Option: C. As a result of fetal anoxemia, there is damage to the liver leading to hypoproteinemia which is responsible for generalized edema (hydrops fetalis), ascites and hydrothorax. Hemolysis caused by the Rh incompatibility, causes extramedullary hematopoiesis in the fetal liver and bone marrow . The push to make more erythroblasts to help compensate for the hemolysis overworks the liver causing hepatomegaly. The resulting liver dysfunction decreases albumin output which in turn decreases oncotic pressure. Consequentially, the decrease in pressure results in overall peripheral edema and ascites. Option: D. Fetal death occurs sooner or later due to cardiac failure. The baby is either stillborn or macerated and even if born alive, dies soon after.

Extraedge:

"Hydrops is characterized by excess fluid in two or more body areas such as thorax, abdomen or skin. It is often associated with hydramnios and a hydropic thickened placenta". It is characterised by: Placental enlargement Pleural effusion Ascites Increased skin thickness (> 5 mm) / skin oedema (first sign seen on USG). com The fetus is in the Buddha position with a halo around the head.

questions.text: A 37-Year-old primi Rh-negative patient is very concerned about her pregnancy at this age. Her pregnancy is 16 weeks and she is HIV negative, hepatitis B surface Ag neg, Rubella nonimmune and has no complaints. Her triple test report is normal but still, due to her age, she insists on getting an amniocentesis done. Which of the following is the next best step in management:

options.label: A
options.text: Advise against amniocentesis as it will increase the risk of isoimmunization

options.label: B
options.text: Follow Rh titres carefully and give Anti D if evidence of isoimmunization is present

options.label: C
options.text: Give Anti-D at 28 weeks of pregnancy and after delivery if the baby is Rh neg

options.label: D
options.text: Give Anti-D prior to her amniocentesis

questions.correct_answer: D. Give Anti-D prior to her amniocentesis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give Anti-D prior to her amniocentesis Primi patient with Rh negative blood group She is 37 years old-elderly primi (>30 years) and has a risk of Down syndrome (>35 years) She is concerned about the risk of having a Down syndrome baby at this age and so insists on having amniocentesis done.

Highyeild:

Dose: Ideally, the amount of Anti-D should be calculated according to the volume of fetomaternal bleeding by doing a Kleihauer test. Generally: Gestational age < 12 weeks - dose is 50μg Beyond 12 weeks - the dose is 300μg Antepartum prophylaxis: At 28 weeks gestation in an Rh-negative patient: An indirect Coombs test is done and if antibodies are not detected i.e. the patient is unimmunised, Anti D 300 µg is given as antepartum prophylaxis. 300 µg of Anti-D will neutralize about 30 ml of feto-maternal bleed (i.e. approximately 15 ml of the fetal cell). Role of postpartum prophylaxis: Anti-D immunoglobulin given postpartum binds to antigen sites on the fetal red cells so that these cells cannot mount an immune response and thus prevent future sensitisation and the next pregnancy. If after delivery, the fetus has a positive direct Coombs test, it means that the mother is already immunized. In such cases, there is no point in giving anti-D.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Advise against amniocentesis as it will increase the risk of isoimmunisation –although the risk of isoimmunization will be increased still I will not advise her against amniocentesis seeing her age and her concern. Option: B. Follow Rh titres carefully and give Anti D if evidence of isoimmunization is present. Anti-d should be given only if evidence of isoimmunization is absent. If isoimmunization is present it means antibodies are already formed, hence no need for giving Anti-D. Option: C. Give Anti D at 28 weeks of pregnancy and after delivery if the baby is Rh negative. If the baby is Rh-negative, no need to give Anti-D.

questions.text: Anti-D prophylaxis should be given in all of the following conditions except:

options.label: A
options.text: Medical abortion for 63 days pregnant

options.label: B
options.text: Amniocentesis at 16 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) is given to unimmunized Rh-negative mothers with Rh-positive fetuses to prevent active immunization and the formation of antibodies against fetal RBCs. The Anti-D binds to antigen sites on the fetal red cells so that these cells do not mount an immune response, provided the baby is Rh negative and the direct Coombs test done on the baby is negative. If the mother’s IUT is positive or the fetus has a positive direct Coombs test, it means the mother is already immunized. In such cases, there is no point in giving anti-D. Anti-D Prophylaxis is given in the following cases.

Role of postpartum prophylaxis: Anti-D immunoglobulin given postpartum binds to antigen sites on the fetal red cells so that these cells cannot mount an immune response and thus prevent future sensitisation and the next pregnancy. If after delivery, the fetus has a positive direct Coombs test, it means that the mother is already immunized. In such cases, there is no point in giving anti-D.

questions.text: The correct statement regarding Rh-incompatibility is:

options.label: A
options.text: Serial USG can diagnose hydrops early

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody titre > 4 IU/ml in mother indicate severe risk of hemolysis

options.label: C
options.text: The prognosis does not depend on parity

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in ABO incompatibility

questions.correct_answer: A. Serial USG can diagnose hydrops early
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serial USG can diagnose hydrops early Erythroblastosis fetalis / Rh incompatibility leads to immune hydrops which can be d iagnosed by serial USG as cardinal signs of hydrops fetalis viz scalp edema, ascites, pleural and pericardial effusion can all be detected on USG. The prognosis depends on both parity and ABO incompatibility.

Highyeild:

Conditions predisposing to isoimmunization in Rh-ve female • Abortion, ectopic pregnancy, molar pregnancy • Chorionic villous sampling, • Cordocentesis • Trauma • Amniocentesis • Antepartum hemorrhage • Attempted version • Vaginal delivery • Manual removal of placenta • Cesarean section

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option B. Antibodies titre: Antibody titre can be measured by automated tests. A titre of < 4 IU/ml is considered as safe. Titre of > 4 IU/ml or 1: 8 denotes isoimmunization. Titre of > 10 IU/ml (in some countries > 15 IU/mL) denotes severe hemolysis – it is also called the ‘critical titre’ Time for performing indirect Coombs test . In primigravida – at 12 weeks or booking visit and if it is negative (i.e. mother is not immunized), it is repeated at 28 weeks. In multigravida – at 12 weeks or booking visit and then at monthly intervals after 28 weeks. Option C . Prognosis depends on parity . 1st pregnancy is usually unaffected Option D . ABO incompatibility : If ABO is present along with Rh incompatibility it protects against Rh isoimmunization. ABO blood group compatibility of mother and fetus - ABO incompatibility protects against Rh isoimmunization. When ABO-incompatible fetal red cells enter the mother’s bloodstream, they quickly combine with the naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B agglutinins and are neutralized by sequestration in the liver. On the other hand, ABO-compatible fetal red cells will persist in the mother’s circulation and thus stimulate the immune response.

Extraedge:

Mechanism of antibody formation in the mother : If the ABO is compatible (mother and fetus have the same ABO group or when the fetus is group "O"), Rh-positive fetal red cells enter the mother's blood, and they remain in circulation for their remaining lifespan. Thereafter, they are removed from circulation by the reticuloendothelial tissues and are broken down with the liberation of the antigen. The antibody production is related not only to the responsiveness of the reticuloendothelial system but also to the amount of Rh antigen liberated, therefore to the number of red cells that have entered the maternal blood. Because this takes a long time, immunization in a first pregnancy is unlikely. Detectable antibodies usually develop after 6 months following a larger volume of fetomaternal bleed. But, if the fetomaternal bleed is less than 0.1 mL, the antibody may not be detected until boosted by further Rh stimulus. Antibodies once formed remain throughout life.

questions.text: The consequences of Rh-incompatibility are not serious during the first pregnancy because:

options.label: A
options.text: In the first pregnancy, only the IgM antibody is formed

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody titer is very low during a primary immune response

options.label: C
options.text: IgG generated is ineffective against fetal red cells

options.label: D
options.text: Massive hemolysis is compensated by increased erythropoiesis

questions.correct_answer: A. In the first pregnancy, only the IgM antibody is formed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In the first pregnancy, only the IgM antibody is formed The initial antibodies which are produced are of IgM variety which cannot cross the placenta and by the time IgG antibodies develop, the patient has already delivered. Thus, the first pregnancy is safe. Another reason is in sensitized women, anti-D antibodies are produced at such a low level that they are not detected during or after the index pregnancy . Instead, they are identified early in a subsequent pregnancy when rechallenged by another D-positive fetus.

Highyeild:

Types of antibodies - Two types of antibodies are formed: IgM-This type of antibody is the first to appear in the maternal circulation and agglutinates red cells containing D when suspended in saline. IgM being larger molecules cannot pass through the placental barrier and is not harmful to the fetus. IgG-It is also called incomplete or blocking antibody. It will agglutinate the red cells containing D only when suspended in 20% albumin. Because of its small molecule, it can cross the placental barrier and cause damage to the fetus. It appears at a later period than does the IgM antibody. It is important to recognize the preponderance of one or the other type of antibody than the actual level of the titer.
